clinical_study.brief_title: Digital Health Nudging in Adolescents With Congenital Heart Disease
clinical_study.official_title: Digital Health Nudging - Daily Smartphone Messages to Increase Physical Activity in Adolescents With Congenital Heart Disease

collaborator.agency: Institute of Preventive Pediatrics, Technical University of Munich

brief_summary.textblock: In adolescents with congenital heart disease physical activity level is reduced which is why promotion to a more active lifestyle with an age-appropriate and modern intervention is needed. In healthy subjects digital health nudging was shown to increase physical activity. However, in adolescents with congenital heart disease such studies have not been conducted yet. In this RCT participants receive daily, short smartphone messages with the primary purpose to increase daily physical activity, which is monitored with a "Garmin vivofit jr." wearable.

primary_outcome.description: Physical activity is objectively assessed with the wrist worn wearable "Garmin vivofit jr.". Daily physical activity is measured on the basis of active minutes in moderate-to-vigorous intensity.

secondary_outcome.description: Daily step count is objectively assessed with the wrist worn wearable "Garmin vivofit jr.".

Perceived self-efficacy in the context of physical activity is measured using the German version of the Physical Activity Self-Efficacy Scale. The scale consists of eight items, each of which is answered on a five-point Likert scale.

Health-related quality of life is self-assessed via the KINDL速 questionnaire. The KINDL速 is a generic instrument for assessing health-related quality of life in children and adolescents. The KINDL速 is a short, methodologically tested and flexible measurement instrument consisting of 24 questions on the six areas of body/physis, feelings/psychology, self-assessment, family, friends and school.

arm_group.description: During 12-week intervention period participants receive daily text messages via WhatsApp on their smartphone to encourage them to be physically active in their daily lives.
During 12-week control period participants receive no text messages.

intervention.description: Short daily text messages with information and motivation concerning physical activity.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Adolescents aged 12 to 18 years inclusive
- Presence of a congenital heart defect (must be moderate or complex according to ACC criteria)
- Presence of written informed consent
Exclusion Criteria:
- Cognitive impairments that inhibit patients from understanding the tasks
